playing Persona 4.

blind, knock yourself out.

ok, so i'm confused

top_comment.author: YouAre NotSugoi

comments.text:
The problem with ensemble games like P4A and PQ is that writers now need to 
work with 20+ characters, and in PQ at least, none of the main P3 or P4 
cast's arcs can be fully resolved. With Aigis, anyway, she acts robotic in 
PQ, but her humanity begins to show just before Shinji dies. It's not like 
New Year's rolled around, and she was suddenly acting human.
comments.author: Logan Graham

comments.text:
+YouAre NotSugoi
Yeah, thats what I heard was a problem in Persona Q, everyone now has a one 
note personality and stuff. In P4 Chie loved meat but she never said it to 
an annoying extent, now thats all she talks about. Teddie is also really 
annoying, and Yosuke is now the buttmonkey and doesn't know who the fuck is 
Saki. And yeah, FeMC isn't canon but Theo is, the game takes place in 
october before Shinji dies, and Aigis being human is just bad writing.

links for the same reason P4A doesn't.
comments.author: masalps

comments.text:
+masalps
But they were fighting games, so it would make sense for it to NOT have 
social links. Persona Q is an RPG, the same genre as Persona 3 and 4. And 
while they don't have social links, we still have Strolls (Which are 
basically social links but are just there to get to know your party) and 
Group Date Cafe to know your soulmate.

comments.author: AlexTenThousand

captions.text: There’s a

world of possibility if you coat an existing
game with another property. Give Doki Doki

Panic a coat of Mario Paint, and you get what
we called Mario 2. Give Shiren the Wanderer

a coat of Pokemon paint, and you get Pokemon
Mystery Dungeon. Give Guilty Gear a coat of

Persona 4 paint, and you’ve got… well,
Persona 4 Arena. And Atlus weren’t satisfied

stopping there. So instead of bending Arc
System Works’ ear again, they took their

idea down the hall to where Etrian Odyssey
is developed, and.... pow. Persona Q: Shadow

of the Labyrinth, which might as well be called
“Persona 3 and 4 get mashed up and pushed

through the Etrian Odyssey Filter subtitle
Hope You Like Maps.” Because that’s just
what it is.

It’s important to understand, though, just
where this game lies. After all, the whole

canon between Persona 3 and 4 has already
been fleshed out through two entries in the

P4A series, where time works like you’d
expect, the Gekkoukan students from Persona

3 are, in fact, 3 years older than their counterparts
from Yasogami High and Persona 4, and there’s

a new crisis involving the TV worlds in Inaba
and Labrys shows up and all that jazz. Well,

throw that out the window. There’s been
a time rift, and the casts of both games - plus

the outlier characters from the remakes like
Theodore and Marie - find themselves stuck

in a spatially-dubious version of Yasogami,
where everyone’s stuck inside a big ol’

school Culture Festival. Every classroom is
set up as a game room, or a cafeteria, or

a display of some sort… including four which
lead to massive, multi-floor, Etrian Odyssey-style
dungeons.

And here’s where the real magic happens:
The game blends the casts of two games, while

blending the mechanics of three, into a stiff
foam that tastes great AND is less filling.

The long-form, life-threatening delves from
the Etrian series return in force, where you

have to draw every map yourself and scour
every corner of each floor for shortcuts and

items to potentially make your life easier.
The combat blends the two-line, five-unit

team structure of Etrian with the weakness-targetting
mechanics of Persona, where striking an enemy’s

Achilles heel grants that character a Boost
status that allows them to act first in the

next combat round and reduces the cost for
skills to 0. And following the Persona mechanics,

you can ask for support and data from Fuuka
and Rise.

Despite their stark differences, these two
series actually gel rather well together,

and that’s partly because they’re blending
two different flavors of unflinchingly brutal

RPG. Fortunately, if you just want to see
the story of two casts of Persona games forced

to deal with each other as equals, you have
the option of dialing down the difficulty

like a wimp. On the other hand, there are
two settings harder than Normal as well, if

you want your brain to run out your ears like
so much maple syrup. If you’re coming from

the Etrian Odyssey side, you might be playing
a bit of catch-up on the backstory, though

any particularly crucial bits of plot are
brought right out in the open. After all,

each team doesn’t know the other in this
particular world, so what looks like two groups

of persona-users getting to know one another
also counts as sufficient exposition for newcomers

who just wanna draw some maps and beat up
some FOEs. The character art represents a

chibi-fied take on the iconic Shigenori Soejima
artwork, maintaining the basics of style while

being utterly adorable. In keeping with form,
it comes alongside another unbelievable Shoji

Meguro soundtrack, with enough odd mashups
of hip-hop and energetic Engrish lyrics to
fuel all of your delves.

If you were waiting with bated breath for
Etrian Odyssey Untold II, Persona Q will help

you pass the time… but if you also happen
to be a Persona fan, Q just might be the cleverest

gadget this side of Desmond Llewelyn. It’s
not without a couple foibles, though: Some

of the mechanics, including the intricacies
of Persona fusion and how to utilize skills

on your Support Team’s Personas, aren’t
really covered in detail and have to be searched

out. The request system has you re-covering
a lot of ground, and often demands that some

underleveled character from your reserves
be included for arbitrary reasons. And, despite

the power to re-purchase any Persona you’ve
registered, it’ll be some time before you

actually have the cash to do so. This is alleviated
a bit by a couple free DLC Personas like Orpheus

Telos and Kaguya, which can boost you through
the early game if you need; if you’re a

hardcore fan of either series, though, chances
are you’re going to scoff at the gimmes

and dig right into one of the best RPGs of
the year. Especially if you like stealth Sazae-san
references.

title: CGR Undertow - PERSONA Q SHADOW OF THE LABYRINTH review for Nintendo 3DS
